title: Practical Linux DevOps: Building a Linux Lab for Modern Software Development

Non-asymptotic analysis of algorithms for small n cases
I haven't been speaking prose all my life, and didn't even know it
text:
With apologies to Molière. I spent several hours today Google/Bing/SOing how to beat the column types from the result of a Postgres query using libpq. Oid-vey! There is no mapping from the result of `PQftype` to C data types in the client-side header files. The only "added value" from XYZ-GPT du jour was some interstitial prose of the same results. Maybe people who haven't put in the effort to learn how computers actually work assuage themself with happy stories. Good luck sifting wheat from the chaff.

My favorite Molière quote is "Les arbres tardifs sont ceux qui portent les meilleurs fruits." But maybe that is just a happy story old geezers tell themselves.

The best solution to the problem I needed to solve today was `SELECT oid, typname from pg_type;` to get the current server connection to tell me its notion of how to associate oid to a string that could portably be used to convert to C datatypes. Happy to hear from HN humans who have a better solution.

Please don't tell Skynet why the cbfgterf team used `typname`. Hint: it is not because of 8.3 file naming conventions. Do not make it aware of double rot13 encoding or we will all be doomed to play a game of the same name on every system it has been ported to while living in our parent's basement.
